bibl.title: Despatch from J. N. Lewis to William H. Seward
Notes from Liberian Legation In U.S. to Department of State, 1862-1898 T807

div1.p:
The undersigned, Secretary of State for the Republic of Liberia, has the honor to communicate with your Excellency, and to represent that the President of the Republic of Liberia appreciating very highly the friendly relations which exist between the Government of the United States and Liberia, is desirous that this relation may be
His Excellency,
The Secretary of State of the United States of America
Washington City D.C.
U.S.A.
be made to yield the greatest amount of benefit to both Governments. He considers that the affinity of the respective Governments should encourage a disposition to strengthen this relation when an opportunity offers, so as to secure the mutual advantages which it is calculated to promote. He is not forgetful, in this solicitation, of the disparity, in point of ability, between the Government of Liberia, the offspring, and that of the mother Republic.

Nevertheless, he is of the opinion that the capability of Liberia to administer importantly to the commerce of the United States would justify an arrangement between the two Governments by which they
they could be mutually benefited to an unprecedented extent.
These considerations have prompted the President of Liberia to direct, that an inquiry be most respectfully communicated to Your Excellency of the following character:

Whether the commercial transactions of the citizens of the United States with Liberians might no be expanded by a proper discrimination between the products of free and slave labor, in the form of a moderation of the duties on Sugar, Coffee, Camwood and Palm Oil imported into the United States by Liberian vessels or the vessels of citizens of the
United States.

Second. Whether in view of the necessity in Liberia of the proper class of immigrants to build up and strengthen her, and to contribute to the development of her resources and in view of the necessity of the emigration of the colored people of the United States, the Government of the U. States would consent to facilitate an undertaking by Liberia to attract and bring to her shores, such of these people as might be willing to emigrate.

Referring to the first query, it is only necessary to invite Your Excellency's attention to these facts: that the Commerce of Liberia, yet in its incipiency, cannot,
cannot, for some years, under the influence of a competition with the products of older states, especially those of slave labor, became as vigorous and profitable as it would: that the work of enfranchisement and the abrogation of the slave trade, in which the Government of the United States takes preeminently the lead, would be by the difficulty of introducing the products of slave labor into the U. States; and the fact, known too well to be named, that the Government of H. B. Majesty impose no duty on Palm Oil introduced into Her dominion
dominion from the Coast of Africa.

On the subject of the second query, it is proper to remark that the difficulty of procuring a class of immigrants much needed in the whole country and especially to occupy contested points clearly within the political jurisdiction of the Republic of Liberia, will constrain the Government of Liberia herself, to invite and emigrate them by the permission of and aid of the Mother Republic.
With sentiments of the highest consideration.

I have the honor to be Your excellency's most obedient servant
J. N. Lewis
